How To Become A Certified Diabetes Educator Pharmacist

If you are a pharmacist with a passion for helping patients manage their diabetes, becoming a Certified Diabetes Educator (CDE) can be a rewarding career path. As a CDE pharmacist, you will have the knowledge and skills to provide comprehensive diabetes education and support to individuals living with diabetes. Here are the steps to becoming a certified diabetes educator pharmacist:

  1. Obtain a PharmD degree: To become a pharmacist, you must complete a Doctor of Pharmacy (PharmD) degree from an accredited pharmacy school. This program typically takes four years to complete and includes coursework in pharmacology, therapeutics, and patient care.

  2. Gain experience in diabetes management: While in pharmacy school or during your professional career, seek opportunities to gain experience in diabetes management. This can include working in a pharmacy that specializes in diabetes care, volunteering at diabetes clinics, or participating in diabetes-related research projects.

  3. Complete the required practice hours: To be eligible for the Certified Diabetes Educator exam, you must have at least two years of professional practice experience as a pharmacist. During this time, you should focus on gaining experience in diabetes management and education.

  4. Attend a diabetes education program: To become a CDE pharmacist, you must complete a diabetes education program that is recognized by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators (NCBDE). These programs provide the necessary knowledge and skills to effectively educate and support individuals with diabetes.

  5. Pass the Certified Diabetes Educator exam: Once you have completed the required practice hours and attended a recognized diabetes education program, you are eligible to take the Certified Diabetes Educator exam. This exam assesses your knowledge and competency in diabetes management and education.

  6. Maintain your certification: To maintain your CDE pharmacist certification, you must complete continuing education credits and renew your certification every five years. This ensures that you stay up-to-date with the latest advancements in diabetes management and education.

Becoming a Certified Diabetes Educator pharmacist requires dedication, commitment, and a genuine desire to help individuals with diabetes live healthier lives. By following these steps, you can embark on a fulfilling career as a CDE pharmacist and make a positive impact on the lives of your patients.
